revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Marilyn | image = Marilyn in München.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Marilyn in [[Munich]], January 1984 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Peter Antony Robinson | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1962|11|3}} | birth_place = [[Kingston, Jamaica]] | origin = London, England, UK | genre = [[New wave music|New wave]], pop, dance | instrument = Vocals | occupation = Singer, songwriter | years_active = 1983–85, 1989, 2000–03, 2016 | label = [[Phonogram Records|Phonogram]] (1983–85)
Interbeat (1989)
Desilu Records (2000)}} '''Peter Robinson''' (born 3 November 1962, [[Kingston, Jamaica]]){{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/marilyn-mn0000825079|title=Biography|work=allmusic.com|accessdate=30 July 2018}} better known as '''Marilyn''', is a British/Jamaican{{cite web|url=http://mistermarilyn.com/biography/|title=Bandar Bola Tangkas Online|website=mistermarilyn.com}} pop singer and songwriter. He is most well known for his 1983 hit "[[Calling Your Name]]" and his highly [[Androgyny|androgynous]] appearance. ==Early life== Robinson was born in Kingston, Jamaica. At age 5, he moved with his mother to [[Borehamwood]], Hertfordshire.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/sep/27/marilyn-peter-robinson-sat-in-room-20-years-taking-crack-watching-alien-films|title=Marilyn: ‘I sat in a room for 20 years, taking crack and watching the Alien films’|first=Alexis|last=Petridis|date=27 September 2016|website=the Guardian}} He left school at 15, and has stated that he was bullied at school for being feminine, and that he self-harmed.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oaycQqdbat0|title=Toby Mott in conversation with Marilyn|first=|last=ICA|date=6 June 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}} ==The Marilyn persona== As a boy, Robinson loved Marilyn Monroe's image, and Marilyn became his school nickname. While the name originated from homophobic bullies at school, Robinson decided to appropriate it to his advantage.{{cite magazine |last1= Sheaf|first1=Claire|title= Marilyn (interview)|magazine= Smash Hits|volume= 5|issue= 22|page=30|publisher= EMAP Metro|date=27 October 1983}} As a teenager, he was a regular nightclub-goer and wanted to look different, so he adopted a [[Marilyn Monroe]] image wearing vintage dresses with bleached blond hair. He became part of the British [[New Romantic]] movement which emerged in the late 1970s club scene and was popularised in the early 1980s. Robinson was a regular at 'The Blitz' nightclub (regulars being labelled as [[Blitz Kids]]), a highly stylised club in London run by [[Steve Strange]] of the pop group [[Visage (band)|Visage]], and a place which spawned many early 1980s pop stars such as [[Spandau Ballet]]. During this time, Robinson met [[Boy George]] (prior to his forming [[Culture Club]]), and the pair would later share a squat together. In 1979, Robinson appeared in the documentary ''Steppin' Out'' directed by [[Lyndall Hobbs]], which explored the fashionable nightclubs and the trendy pop culture scenes that were famous in London in the late 70s. It was shown as the support film to ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]'' in British cinemas. Also in 1979, he appeared in the first segment of director [[Derek Jarman]]'s 12-minute short film ''Broken English''. While Boy George went on to form [[Culture Club]] in 1981 and secured a recording deal with Virgin Records, Marilyn was still scouting for a recording contract and had relocated to Los Angeles for some time. There, he worked as a personal assistant to daytime soap star [[Terry Lester]],{{cite magazine |last1= Tebbutt|first1= Simon|title= News Beat: Some Like It Hot (an interview with Marilyn)|magazine=Number One Magazine|page=19|publisher= IPC Magazines|date=6 August 1983}} and teamed up with songwriter and pop entrepreneur [[Paul Caplin]] who became his manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.carlinmusic.com/songs/page/songId/244|title=Carlin Music UK - 100 years of Music|website=www.carlinmusic.com}} ==Music career: 1980s== After Marilyn's friend Boy George had made a commercial impact with Culture Club, record companies were looking for other artists with a similar cross-dressing image. In 1983, following a high-profile appearance in the promo video for [[Eurythmics]]' hit single, "[[Who's That Girl? (Eurythmics song)|Who's That Girl?]]",{{cite web|url=http://www.gayinthe80s.com/2013/10/1983-music-eurhythmics-whos-that-girl/|title=1983. Music: Eurhythmics. Who's That Girl? - Gay in the 80s|date=10 October 2013|publisher=}} Robinson signed his own recording contract as Marilyn with [[Phonogram Records]]. Marilyn's first chart success came in late 1983 with his debut single "[[Calling Your Name]]"[http://www.britishchartsingles.com/index.php/2013/11/27/calling-your-name-marilyn/ British Chart Singles] which reached the Top 5 in the UK and Australia, and number 1 in Japan.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} He had two further minor UK Top 40 hits in 1984 with "Cry and Be Free" and "You Don't Love Me" (the latter of which he performed at the Children's Royal Variety Performance held at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]], London, in the presence of [[HRH The Princess Anne]]). In March 1984, Marilyn flew to Australia for a 10-day promotional tour and was besieged by fans who were waiting to greet him at Melbourne Airport. Film footage of his arrival was broadcast on that evening's television news.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0TYvT5eSLRw&list=UUO7Qcft9wFunFllP63iiClA|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=grMU3PaMwHY|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com}} While in Australia, he was attacked and kicked in the face by a member of the public at the Exchange Hotel, a gay bar venue in Sydney, sustaining a bruised eye from the incident.[http://www.theblitzkids.com/site_archive/blitz_kids/marilyn.html Blitz Kids (clippings)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421082458/http://www.theblitzkids.com/site_archive/blitz_kids/marilyn.html |date=21 April 2014 }} In late 1984, Marilyn took part in the [[Band Aid (band)|Band Aid]] charity single "[[Do They Know It's Christmas]]" along with various other pop stars of the era.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/feed-the-world-band-aid-25-years-on-1825385.html?action=gallery&ino=27|title=Feed the world? Band Aid 25 years on|publisher=}} In early 1985, now facing financial difficulties and being forced to give up his London home, Phonogram Records dispatched him to Detroit, Michigan, to work with producer [[Don Was]]. While in America he cut his trademark long blonde hair short and ceased wearing make-up, abandoning the image that had brought him his initial success. After spending a week recording new material with Was, Marilyn was scheduled to perform live for the first time at New York's famed [[Area (nightclub)|Area nightclub]]. The performance was intended to be filmed for use in the promo video for his new single, "Baby U Left Me", but the film crew were delayed, and although Marilyn proceeded to go onstage anyway, the performance was ruined by technical problems with the club's [[public address|PA system]]. Midway through his first song, Marilyn abandoned the performance.{{cite magazine |last1= Tennant|first1= Neil|last2= |first2= |title= Marilyn - Does Anyone Still Want Him?|magazine= Smash Hits|volume= 7|issue= 6|pages=26, 27|publisher= EMAP Metro|date=14 March 1985}} In June 1985, Marilyn released his debut album, ''[[Despite Straight Lines]]''. Despite including his three earlier UK Top 40 hit singles, the album only charted in Australia. Further singles from the album, "Baby U Left Me" and "Pray for That Sunshine" were unsuccessful, although the former reached the top 40 in Australia. By this time, Robinson's drug addiction and his highly publicised disputes with Boy George damaged his public image. Public tastes were also changing, and his music career suffered. Despite the problems in New York the year before, Marilyn performed live once in December 1986 at the Mud Club in London, where he performed a cover version of "[[Spirit in the Sky]]" which was planned to be his new single but was never released.[http://www.theblitzkids.com/site_archive/yurayaya/mazmud86/index.html Marilyn at the Mud Club (MazMag, 1986)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421051104/http://www.theblitzkids.com/site_archive/yurayaya/mazmud86/index.html |date=21 April 2014 }} By 1989, Robinson had signed with the Interbeat label, though again no new recordings surfaced. He then dropped out of the public eye for the next decade, abandoning his music career. ==Activities from late 1990s-2006== Robinson first re-appeared in 1999 when he was interviewed on the [[Channel 4]] programme ''Top Ten New Romantics'', though he himself was not listed in the chart. In 2000, he attempted to relaunch his career and recorded a new single as Marilyn, a cover version of the [[Dennis Brown]] song "How Could I Live?" for Desilu Records based in Jamaica.[http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xbhvvb_marilyn-how-could-i-live-2001_music Daily Motion] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419191332/http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xbhvvb_marilyn-how-could-i-live-2001_music |date=19 April 2014 }} Robinson recorded the track in Jamaica and a few months later producer Nick Cabrera flew out there to supervise the final work on the track and its subsequent remixes. German producer Kinky Roland also made a remix of the track.{{cite web|url=http://www.nickcabrera.com|title=Nick Cabrera Photography|website=www.nickcabrera.com}} Following disagreements with the label, Robinson refused to let the single be released, though some 12" promotional copies do exist. In 2001, Robinson appeared in the BBC documentary programme ''A Fine Romance: The Story of the New Romantics''. On 2 September 2001, Marilyn performed a live appearance at the ''Sound on Sunday'' club night in Leicester Square, London. It was his first live performance in over 14 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.circa-club.com/gallery/gay_history_icons_marilyn_peter_robinson.php|title=Gay History, Gay Celebrities, Gay Icons - Marilyn ( Peter Robinson ) - Circa - Club for Gay Professional Men|first=Global Websuites|last=Limited|website=www.circa-club.com}} To promote the gig, Robinson gave a series of magazine interviews.Marilyn quotes, from 'The Marilyn Files' by Stewart Who? QX magazine, 29 August 2001, No. 345, pages 24–26: "When we discuss the long exile, he feels there's nothing to explain. 'I don't go round looking for publicity ... because I've done that already.' He's just beginning to comprehend the cult status and level of support on offer. If he could only help himself: 'It's shocking to me. I haven't tuned into anything for years. Or thought about work, because I've been a junkie. No one was in my bubble but me. My outlook has been, will the last person leaving, switch the light out'."Extract from an interview with Marilyn – ‘She's back’ in The Pink Paper, 31 August 2001, issue 701, page 15: "Few can remember just how huge Marilyn was in the early 80s, when, with other characters like Steve Strange, Leigh Bowery and one George O'Dowd, he crossed from club-scene mannequin to mainstream diva."Extract from ‘Karma Chameleon’ in Boyz magazine, 1 September 2001, issue 526, page 33. "Way back in the day, when Liam Gallager was still at school, Patsy Kensit was in Eighth Wonder (just about) and Duran Duran had the biggest hair on the planet (apart from George Michael and Bonnie Tyler of course), homosexuality was sadly still just about as uncouth as not replacing the toilet roll... only about ten times so. Therefore, it's not hard to imagine the dramatic effect the likes of gender benders Boy George and Marilyn had on society at large. Gay and straight boys alike went wild with mascara, whilst mothers and grannies, well, er... we joined them!" A 4-track self-pressed CD-R of older material was released privately in 2003.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Marilyn-Hold-On-Tight/release/1954162|title=Marilyn - Hold On Tight|website=Discogs}} The same year, Robinson appeared on the [[Channel 4]] television show ''[[The Salon]]'', a reality show based at a hairdressing salon where members of the public and several celebrities went for haircuts and beauty treatments. He also appeared in the TV documentary ''25 Years of Smash Hits'' that traced the influence of UK pop music. In 2006, Robinson was interviewed in the [[Channel 4]] TV documentary ''Whatever Happened to the Gender Benders?'', which reflected on the advent of the New Romantic movement of the early 1980s and the prominent roles that he, Boy George and Steve Strange played within it. ==Career since 2013== On 16 May 2013, Robinson appeared on Birmingham's Switch Radio where he gave a 30-minute interview.{{cite web|url=http://www.switchradio.co.uk/viewnews.asp?id=47|title=Switch Radio|publisher=}} The following month, he appeared on Kev Gurney's ''Club Tropicana'' radio show on Bolton 96.5 radio where he gave a 20-minute interview in which he speaks candidly about his life. During the interview he revealed that he has been back in the recording studio and is currently working on four new tracks with a new production team, and suggested the possibility of live dates in the future.[https://soundcloud.com/kevingurney/marilyn Soundcloud] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419014806/https://soundcloud.com/kevingurney/marilyn |date=19 April 2014 }} He appeared on an episode of Celebrity Gogglebox that aired on Channel 4 on 9 October 2015 as part of the channel's Stand Up To Cancer Charity Evening.{{Cite web|title = Boy George, Miranda Hart and Jamie Dornan to appear in Gogglebox celebrity special|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/11918598/Boy-George-and-Geri-Halliwell-to-appear-in-Gogglebox-celebrity-special.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-10-09}} Robinson began reporting on his Facebook page in Spring 2015 that he has been writing and recording some new material with [[Boy George]] as producer, and some re-recordings of his back catalogue. He spoke about the new recordings at length during a June 2016 interview. On 23 September 2016, Marilyn released his first new single in over 30 years, entitled "Love or Money".{{cite web|url=http://www.boygeorgeuk.com/?p=6232|title=MISTER MARILYN
LOVE OR MONEY|first=|last=admin|publisher=}} The same day, both he and Boy George appeared on the television show ''[[BBC Breakfast]]'', which showed the promo video for the single. The pair were also interviewed on ''[[Loose Women]]'' on 26 September 2016. ==Personal life== Robinson was born in Jamaica, but after his parents split up, he and his mother moved back to England when he was four years old, settling in Hertfordshire. After being constantly bullied, he left school at 15, and by 1979 he had left home and was living in a squat in London. Robinson has been candid about the effect drug abuse has had on his life, and the physical and mental health problems he has suffered. In 1986, both he and Boy George were arrested in London on charges of drug possession. On 20 August 1986, at Marylebone Magistrates Court in London, a magistrate dismissed a heroin charge against Robinson because the prosecution offered no evidence.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-08-20/news/mn-18506_1_heroin-charge|title=British Drug Charge Against Pop Singer Marilyn Dismissed|first=Associated|last=Press|date=20 August 1986|publisher=|via=LA Times}} In a November 2014 interview with the Daily Mirror, he said that he was a heroin addict from the mid-1980s to the mid-2000s.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/band-aid-star-marilyn-spent-4611526|title=Band Aid star spent decades battling heroin and poverty after recording track|first=Melissa|last=Thompson|date=11 November 2014|publisher=}} Robinson says he has been clear of all drugs since 2010, after a period in rehab prompted by some specific severe health problems. In his 1995 autobiography ''[[Take It Like a Man (autobiography)|Take It Like a Man]]'', [[Boy George]] wrote that in the 1980s Robinson had a relationship with singer [[Gavin Rossdale]]. In a 1996 interview for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Rossdale responded: "That's George's take – he doesn't know me. There's a queue of people going to their lawyers about stuff in his book. I hope he manages to sell some books by putting my name in there."[https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5938704/nirvanawannabes ]{{dead link|date=October 2011}} Elsewhere both Rossdale and Robinson initially denied the story{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/2364482/Gavin-Rossdale-is-gay-Boy-George |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223133906/http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/2364482/Gavin-Rossdale-is-gay-Boy-George |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 February 2013 |title=Gavin Rossdale 'gay' – Boy George |date=27 April 2009 |agency=[[Australian Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=1 October 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.intouchweekly.com/2009/04/in_touch_exclusivemarilyn_gavi.php |title=Celebrity news and entertainment from |publisher=In Touch Weekly |date=22 April 2009 |accessdate=17 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004030502/http://www.intouchweekly.com/2009/04/in_touch_exclusivemarilyn_gavi.php |archivedate=4 October 2011 |df=dmy }} but in 2003 Robinson dedicated the Marilyn CD "Hold on Tight" to Rossdale, citing "the years of our passionate relationship" and featuring a photo of them together on the cover. Later, both men spoke more candidly about their relationship, with Robinson confirming in 2009 that they had been "together five years" in the 1980s while in 2010 Rossdale said the relationship with Robinson had been an experimentation and "part of growing up".{{cite web|url=http://perezhilton.com/2010-10-13-gavin-rossdale-confirms-same-sex-hookup-with-cross-dressing-pop-star-marilyn |title=Gavin Rossdale Confirms Same Sex Hook-Up With Cross Dressing Pop Star! |publisher=PerezHilton.com |date=2010-10-13 |accessdate=2014-08-24}}{{cite web|last=Weiner |first=Jonah |url=http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/music-and-books/201011/bush-frontman-lead-singer-gavin-rossdale-interview-gwen-stefani#ixzz12FS7Y4U0 |title=Gavin Rossdale, Uncensored: Music + Books |publisher=Details |date=2010-11-01 |accessdate=2014-08-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1320627/Gwen-Stefanis-husband-Gavin-Rossdales-gay-confession-years-late-says-Marilyn.html|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20140824205042/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1320627/Gwen-Stefanis-husband-Gavin-Rossdales-gay-confession-years-late-says-Marilyn.html|deadurl=yes|title=Gwen Stefani's husband Gavin Rossdale's gay confession is 'years late…|date=24 August 2014|archivedate=24 August 2014|publisher=}} Robinson said, "Gavin and Gwen [Stefani, Rossdale's then-wife] are perfect for each other, but he was the love of my life." == Depictions in culture and media == Exhibitions that have included material relating to Marilyn: Nicola Tyson’s ''2013 Bowie Nights at Billy's Club, London, 1978'' Exhibition at Sadie Coles HQ Gallery, London W1 – 25 January – 23 February 2013 {{cite web|url=http://flashinonthe70s.wordpress.com/2013/02/17/70s-new-romantics-make-an-exhibition-of-themselves-at-sadie-coles-hq-exhibition-in-london/|title=70s New Romantics make an exhibition of themselves at Sadie Coles HQ exhibition in London|date=17 February 2013|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sadiecoles.com/artists-web-app/tyson|title=Sadie Coles|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ica.org.uk/whats-on/culture-now-nicola-tyson-conversation-michael-bracewell|title=Culture Now: Nicola Tyson in Conversation with Michael Bracewell|website=www.ica.org.uk}} Marilyn modelled for several fashion designers including [[Jean Paul Gaultier]] and [[Vivienne Westwood]]{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/142748-Marilyn|title=Marilyn|website=Discogs}} Several photographs of Marilyn are housed in London's [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp10002/marilyn-peter-robinson|title=Marilyn (Peter Robinson) - Person - National Portrait Gallery|website=www.npg.org.uk}} Books that have included references to Marilyn include: ''We Can Be Heroes: Punks, Poseurs, Peacocks and People of a Particular Persuasion'' by Graham Smith, published by Unbound – 20 November 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/the-blitz-kids-how-the-new-romantics-made-london-swing-again-8294639.html|title=The Blitz kids: How the New Romantics made London swing again|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/the-blitz-kids-how-the-new-romantics-made-london-swing-again-8294639.html?action=gallery&ino=8|title=The Blitz kids: How the New Romantics made London swing again|publisher=}}[http://shapersofthe80s.com/2011/10/07/➤-a-taste-of-the-80s-blitz-kids-—-this-photo-book-captures-their-unseen-glory/ Shapers of the 80s] ''Take It Like a Man: The Autobiography of Boy George.'' (1995) Marilyn features prominently in Boy George's autobiography, which reflects on their long friendship and years together from living in a London squat and working at the Blitz Club. In the book, George claims that while they were living in a squat together, they were chased out by a neighbour (male) who was attracted to Marilyn, but who then broke the door down with an axe when he discovered Marilyn was a man. He also claims Marilyn once tried to seduce [[David Bowie]] at a London nightclub but was rebuffed.{{cite book |last= O'Dowd|first=George "Boy George" |date=1995 |title= [[Take It Like a Man (autobiography)|Take It Like a Man]]: The Autobiography of Boy George|location=London |publisher=Harper Collins |isbn=978-0062117786 }} Marilyn has been portrayed in several productions, including Boy George's stage musical ''[[Taboo (musical)|Taboo]]'' which reflected on the [[New Romantic]] scene of the early '80s.MARILYN interview by James Anderson in ''Attitude'' magazine in which Marilyn discusses the forthcoming musical 'Taboo' in which he is portrayed, September 2001, number 89, pages 22–23. "How do you feel about the forthcoming musical, Taboo, based on the early '80s London club legends? 'Originally it was going to be a film – and I'm not sure what I think about it really. The four main characters are Marilyn, Boy George, Steve Strange and Philip Salon. I've got to look at the tapes of the actors' workshops from it round at George's. It's coming from mainly George's angle again [the Boy is writing the music for the show] and that's slightly perturbing to me.' You talk about George like he has some real hold over you? 'I love George, we're friends and we've got a history together. The thing is, he's more famous than me. I don't have the access to the media to be able to say my A-B-C to his D-E-F. People will believe anything someone says it they're a celebrity, and that's sad'." He was also portrayed by the actor [[Freddie Fox (actor)|Freddie Fox]] in the 2010 BBC television film ''[[Worried About the Boy]]'', about the rise of Boy George in the early '80s.{{cite web|url=http://www.hungertv.com/film/feature/fantastic-mr-fox/|title=One From the Archives: FANTASTIC MR FOX: FREDDIE FOX - HUNGER TV|publisher=}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"|Year !rowspan="2"|Album details !Peak chart positions |- !style="width:3em;font-size:75%;"|[[Kent Music Report|AUS]]

{{Infobox person | name = Mick West | image = Mick West.jpg | birth_date = | birth_place = | nationality = British | alma mater = University of Manchester | known_for = Debunking chemtrail theories and explaining UFO sightings | website = {{Flatlist| https://www.metabunk.org http://contrailscience.com }} }}
'''Mick West''' is a science writer, [[scientific skepticism|skeptical]] investigator, and retired video game programmer. He is the creator of the websites ''Contrail Science'' and ''Metabunk'', for which he investigates and debunks [[pseudoscientific]] claims such as [[chemtrails]], [[UFO]]s, and [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theories]], and has appeared in various media as an [[expert]] analyst and science communicator.
==Career== ===Neversoft=== West co-founded [[Neversoft Entertainment]] in July 1994 with Joel Jewett and Chris Ward. The [[video game developer|video game development]] company, known for ''[[Spider-Man (2000 video game)|Spider-Man]]'' and the ''[[Tony Hawk's (series)|Tony Hawk's]]'' and ''[[Guitar Hero]]'' video game franchises, was acquired by [[Activision]] in October 1999,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.giantbomb.com/neversoft-entertainment/3010-1442/ |title=Neversoft Entertainment (Company) |publisher=[[Giant Bomb]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> its studio merged with [[Infinity Ward]] on May 3, 2014 and was made defunct on July 10, 2014.
===Websites=== West became interested in the [[chemtrail conspiracy theory]] while studying aviation weather for his pilot’s license. He created the website “Contrail Science” with the aim of explaining [[contrails]] and debunking chemtrail theories. He believed initially that he could explain and debunk these theories quite quickly, but they were more resilient than he’d anticipated: he has now spent more than 10 years covering the topic.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rogers |first1=Kaleigh |title=Send This Article to All Your Friends Who Believe in Chemtrails |url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/zm8d4e/send-this-article-to-all-your-friends-who-believe-in-chemtrails |website=motherboard.vice.com |publisher=Vice |accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref>
The discussion on the “Contrail Science” website eventually expanded to include other conspiracy theories, including that of [[9/11 conspiracy theories|9/11]]. So West decided to create another website, “Metabunk”, to expand the discussion to other alternative beliefs. Metabunk covers such topics as [[pseudoscience]], [[unidentified flying object|UFO]]s and the [[paranormal]]. The website also includes a forum, “Skydentify”, where West invites people to send photos and videos of UFOs and supposed ghosts. He analyses these using his background in video game programming and [[Photoshop]], and then he and other forum members attempt to explain what the photos and videos are actually depicting. They also discuss the best way to communicate the results of their debunking investigations.<ref name = rs>{{cite podcast |url=http://skepticzone.libsyn.com/the-skeptic-zone-506-1july2018 |title=The Skeptic Zone |website=skepticzone.tv |publisher=The Skeptic Zone Podcast |last1=Saunders |first1=Richard |authorlink=Richard Saunders (skeptic) |date=1 July 2018 |time=2.30 |access-date=25 July 2018}}</ref> Analysis from West and other experts on Metabunk has been cited in other publications, such as [[the Daily Express]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Austin |first1=Jon |title=Is this REAL TRUTH about Pentagon UFO video that convinced world aliens may exist? |url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/weird/904005/Pentagon-UFO-real-truth-US-navy-aliens-may-exist |website=express.co.uk |publisher=Express Newspapers |accessdate=5 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kooser |first1=Amanda |title=UFO caught on video? Skeptics weigh in on weird footage |url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/weird/904005/Pentagon-UFO-real-truth-US-navy-aliens-may-exist |website=cnet.com |publisher=CBS interactive |accessdate=5 August 2018}}</ref> and is frequently discussed on [[Reddit]].
West describes the objective of his work as attempting to get people out of the “rabbit hole” of conspiratorial thinking. “Chemtrails is a surprisingly popular theory; it’s right up there with things like the 9/11 conspiracy theories,” he says. “It all stems from a fundamental distrust of science and authority. You are always going to get a percentage of people who are true believers. My goal is to minimize that as much as possible, stop people falling for it, and help them get out as easily as possible.”<ref name = sg/>
He also created the online forum morgellonswatch.com to dispel the myths and misinformation surrounding the unconfirmed [[skin condition]], [[Morgellons]].<ref name = sts/>
===Academic work=== [[File:Mick West CSICon 2016.jpg|thumb|Mick West speaking at CSICon in 2016]] In August 2016, West co-authored a paper with climate scientists Ken Caldeira, Christine Shearer, and Steven J. Davis published in the journal [[Environmental Research Letters]] titled ''Quantifying expert consensus against the existence of a secret, large-scale atmospheric spraying program (SLAP)''. The objective of the paper was to produce a peer-reviewed expert response to the chemtrail theory. The authors surveyed experts on atmospheric chemistry and deposition to scientifically evaluate the claims of chemtrail conspiracy theorists. Upon publication, it was recognized as the first study by a major science organization on the topic.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sutherland |first1=Scott |title=Scientists conclude 'chemtrail conspiracy' has no substance |url=https://www.theweathernetwork.com/news/articles/scientists-conclude-chemtrail-conspiracy-has-no-substance/71200 |website=theweathernetwork.com |publisher=The Weather Network |accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref> Its conclusion reported that “76 out of 77 (98.7%) scientists that took part in this study said there was no evidence of a SLAP, and that the data cited as evidence could be explained through other factors, such as typical contrail formation and poor data sampling instructions presented on SLAP websites”<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shearer |first1=Christine |last2=West |first2=Mick |last3=Caldeira |first3=Ken |last4=Davis |first4=Stephen |title=Quantifying expert consensus against the existence of a secret, large-scale atmospheric spraying program |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/8/084011/meta |website=iopscience.iop.org |publisher=IOP Publishing |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> Data science company [[Altmetric]], rated the paper in the top 5% of all research, in terms of interest generated and it has been cited many times by scientific publications and news outlets. <ref>{{cite web |title=Quantifying expert consensus against the existence of a secret, large-scale atmospheric spraying program |url=https://www.altmetric.com/details/10396896/news |website=altmetric.com |publisher=Altmetric |accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref> This included the [[New York Times]], where West said the new study should help sway people who might otherwise be convinced by a chemtrails website. “You’re trying to hold back the tide to a certain degree, and hopefully have less people fall into that way of thinking.”<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fountain |first1=Henry |title=Scientists Just Say No to ‘Chemtrails’ Conspiracy Theory |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/16/science/scientists-just-say-no-to-chemtrails-conspiracy-theory.html |website=nytimes.com |publisher=The New York Times Company |accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
West has written articles for the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]'s journal [[Skeptical Inquirer]], such as “Curated Crowdsourcing in UFO Investigations” where he discusses the Skydentify forum<ref>{{cite web |last1=West |first1=Mick |title=Curated Croudsourcing in UFO Investigations. |url=https://www.csicop.org/sb/show/curated_crowdsourcing_in_ufo_investigations |website=csicop.org |publisher=CSI |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref> and “In Defense of Debunkers” in which he talks of the role of skepticism and of debunking and the importance of communication.<ref>{{cite web |last1=West |first1=Mick |title=In Defense of Debunkers |url=https://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/in_defense_of_debunkers |website=csicop.org |publisher=CSI |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, West delivered a presentation at [[CSICon]] titled “Expert Elicitation vs. Chemtrails” in which he discussed his 2016 scientific paper on climate engineering.<ref name = sg>{{cite web |last1=Gerbic |first1=Susan |authorlink= Susan Gerbic |title=From Chemtrails to CSICon: An Interview with Mick West |url=https://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/from_chemtrails_to_csicon_an_interview_with_mick_west |website=csicorp.org |publisher=CSI |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
=== Books === In 2018, West authored ''Escaping the Rabbit Hole. How to Debunk Conspiracy Theories Using Facts, Logic, and Respect'' with the goal of helping people understand and explain conspiracy theories, and then pass those explanations onto others. In a review of the book, British actor [[Stephen Fry]] wrote “Mick West demonstrates with exquisite style, wit, and insight how those three rare and valuable species, Fact, Logic and Respect (each now on the very brink of extinction) have in harness the power to shine light into darkness and dispel the miasma of bias, superstition and balefully proud ignorance that is threatening to poison our age.”<ref>{{cite web |title=Escaping the Rabbit Hole |url=https://www.skyhorsepublishing.com/9781510735804/escaping-the-rabbit-hole/ |website=skyhorsepublishing.com |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref> An extended excerpt from this book was published in [[Salon (website)|Salon]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=West |first1=Mick |title=How to pull a friend out of the conspiracy theory rabbit hole |url=https://www.salon.com/2018/09/16/how-to-pull-a-friend-out-of-the-conspiracy-theory-rabbit-hole/ |website=Salon |publisher=Salon Media Group, Inc |accessdate=18 September 2018}}</ref>
=== Media === West is often cited as an expert analyst on chemtrails and UFOs by the media. In 2010, he appeared on [[CBS]] evening news and [[KPCC]] radio news to comment on a viral video of what appeared to be a "mystery" missile launch.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Martin |first1=David |title="Missile Mystery" Laid to Rest |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/missile-mystery-laid-to-rest/ |website=cbsnews.com |publisher=CBS Interactive Inc. |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Mystery solved: 'Mystery missile' just a jet |url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2010/11/11/20923/mystery-solved-mystery-missile-just-jet/ |website=scpr.org |publisher=Southern California Public Radio |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
In September of 2016, [[Radio New Zealand]] profiled West as a science writer and someone who “is dedicated to the art of debunking wild theories that circulate online and helping other people do the same, with his website, Metabunk.” In the interview he described how his passion for debunking comes from a concern that real problems are being ignored because science is ignored. In particular he talked about the harm conspiracy theorists can cause when they accuse the families of victims of gun massacres as being crisis actors. He also explained that when “dealing with conspiracy theorists the best thing is to be polite. You’ve got to be a kind of gentleman scientist. If people are polite then you will get listened to. Never misrepresent yourself, never lie, never fake evidence, never indulge in hoaxes. You’ve got to be 100% beyond reproach at all times.”<ref name = rnz>{{cite web |title=The man who debunks conspiracy theories |url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/afternoons/audio/201817013/the-man-who-debunks-conspiracy-theories |website=radionz.co.nz |publisher=Radio New Zealand |accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref>
He has also made a number of appearances on podcasts discussing his life and debunking career. These include being interviewed by [[Richard Saunders (skeptic)|Richard Saunders]] on the ''Skeptic Zone''<ref name = rs/> and [[Benjamin Radford]] on ''Squaring the Strange'',<ref name = sts>{{cite web |title=Episode 75 - Escaping the Rabbit Hole with Mick West |url=https://squaringthestrange.libsyn.com/episode-75-escaping-the-rabbit-hole-with-mick-west-0 |website=squaringthestrange.libsyn.com |publisher=Kronos Creative |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref> as well as ''Something You Should Know''.<ref>{{cite web |title=212 Where Conspiracy Theories Come From & Which Do Humans Prefer – Strict or Loose Rules? |url=https://www.somethingyoushouldknow.net/where-conspiracy-theories-come-from-which-do-humans-prefer-strict-or-loose-rules/ |website=somethingyoushouldknow.net |publisher=Something You Should Know |accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref> He has made several appearances on the [[Joe Rogan Experience]] to discuss various conspiracy theories.<ref>{{cite web |title=JRE #1052 - Mick West |url=http://podcasts.joerogan.net/podcasts/mick-west-2 |website=joerogan.net |publisher=Joe Rogan |accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2013, West appeared in the documentary film "Overcast” as a rebuttal to promoters of chemtrail conspiracy theories.<ref>{{cite web |title=Overcast |url=https://www.overcast-the-movie.com |website=overcast-the-movie.com |publisher=Dedal Films |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Overcast - an Investigation Into Climate Engineering |url=http://worldfilmpresentation.com/film/overcast-investigation-climate-engineering |website=worldfilmpresentation.com |publisher=World Film Presentation |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.metabunk.org/ Metabunk] * [http://contrailscience.com/ Contrail Science] * [http://morgellonswatch.com/ Morgellons Watch] * [http://cowboyprogramming.com Mick West] on [[YouTube]] * [https://twitter.com/MickWest Mick West] on [[Twitter]] * {{IMDb name|3245397|Mick West}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:West, Mick}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British sceptics]] [[Category:Critics of conspiracy theories]] [[Category:UFO skeptics]]

revision.text:
{{More footnotes|date=October 2010}} '''Partholón''' (Modern spelling: 'Parthalán') is a character in medieval Irish Christian pseudo-history. By tradition, he is credited with leading a large group to settle in Ireland. The tale is probably an invention of the Christian writers.{{cite book|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=oVaUkHKOyLAC|page=11}}|title=Eyewitness to Irish History|last=Ellis|first=Peter Berresford|date=2 Mar 2007|publisher=John Wiley|isbn=978-0-470-05312-6|edition=2 Rev|page=11|authorlink=Peter Berresford Ellis}} "Partholón" comes from the Biblical name "Bartholomaeus" or "Bartholomew". The name may be borrowed from a character who appears in the Christian pseudo-histories of Saints [[Jerome]] and [[Isidore of Seville]].[[John Carey (Celticist)|Carey, John]]. [http://www.ucc.ie/academic/smg/CDI/PDFs_articles/JCarey_QuigginPamphletsI.pdf ''The Irish National Origin-Legend: Synthetic Pseudohistory'']. [[University of Cambridge]], 1994. p.9 {{cite book|last=Monaghan|first=Patricia|title=The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=nd9R6GQBB_0C|page=376}}|date=14 May 2014|page=376|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1037-0}} == Legend == Partholón was the leader of the second group of people to settle in [[Ireland]], the 'Muintir Partholóin' (People of Partholón). They arrived on the uninhabited island about 300 years after [[Genesis flood narrative|Noah's Flood]] and were believed responsible for introducing activities such as farming, cooking, brewing and building. After some years, they all succumbed to [[Plague (disease)|plague]] in one week. === ''Historia Brittonum'' === The earliest surviving reference to Partholón is in the ''[[Historia Brittonum]]'', a 9th-century British [[Latin language|Latin]] compilation attributed to [[Nennius]]. It says that Ireland was settled three times by three different groups, with 'Partholomus' and his followers arriving first from [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]] with a thousand followers who multiplied until they numbered four thousand before succumbing to the plague in a single week.Giles, J. A. (trans), [https://archive.org/stream/sixoldenglishchr00gileuoft#page/388/mode/2up "Nennius' History of the Britons" §13], ''Six Old English Chronicles'', Bohn's Antiquarian Library, 1848 === ''Lebor Gabála Érenn'' === The ''[[Lebor Gabála Érenn]]'', an 11th-century Christian pseudo-history of Ireland, states that Ireland was settled six times, with Partholón and his followers forming the second group. The number may have been chosen to match the "[[Six Ages of the World]]".[[Marie-Louise Sjoestedt|Sjoestedt, Marie-Louise]] (1949). ''Celtic Gods and Heroes''. Dover Publications, 2000. p.3 According to the ''Lebor Gabála'', Ireland was uninhabited following the deaths of [[Cessair]] and her companions in [[Genesis flood narrative|the Flood]]. It says that Partholón came from [[Ancient Greece|Greece]]{{sfn|Macallister|1940| p= 5}} and was the son of Sera, son of Sru, who was himself a descendant of [[Magog (Bible)|Magog]], [[Japhetites|son of]] [[Japheth]], who was the [[sons of Noah|son of]] [[Noah]]. Partholón and his people sailed to Ireland via [[Sicily]] and Iberia, arriving 300 or 312 years after the flood and landing at [[Inber Scéne]] ([[Kenmare]] in [[County Kerry]]). With Partholón were his wife ([[Dealgnaid|Delgnat]]), their three sons (Slanga, Rudraige and Laiglinne), the sons' wives (Nerba, Cichba and Cerbnad), and a thousand followers. Partholón and all of his people—five thousand men and four thousand women—died of the plague in a single week, on Senmag (the "old plain"), near modern [[Tallaght]]. === ''Foras Feasa ar Érinn'' === [[Geoffrey Keating|Seathrún Céitinn]]'s 17th-century compilation ''[[Foras Feasa ar Éirinn|Foras Feasa ar Érinn]]'' says they arrived in 2061 BC. It claims that Partholón was the son of Sera, the king of Greece, and fled his homeland after murdering his father and mother. He lost his left eye in the attack on his parents. He and his followers set off from [[Greece]], sailed via Sicily and arrived in Ireland from the west, having traveled for two and a half months. According to Céitinn, at the time of Partholón's arrival, Ireland consisted of one open plain, three lakes and nine rivers. Partholóin cleared four more plains, and seven more lakes [[lake-burst|burst from the ground]]. Named figures are credited with having introduced cattle husbandry, ploughing, cooking, dwellings, trade and dividing the island into four parts. In Céitinn's version of the story, at the [[Magh Ithe|Battle of Mag Itha]], the first battle fought in Ireland, the Partholóin battled and defeated the [[Fomorians]], who were led by [[Cichol Gricenchos]]. The Fomorians have been interpreted as a group of [[pagan]] gods associated with the harmful forces of nature. A poem in the ''Lebor Gabála'', expanded by Céitinn, tells how Partholón and his wife, Delgnat, lived on a small island near the head of the estuary of the [[River Erne]]. Once, while Partholón was out touring his domain, Delgnat seduced a servant named Topa. Afterward, they drank from Partholón's [[ale]], which could only be accessed through a golden tube. Partholón discovered the affair when he drank his ale and recognized the taste of Delgnat's and Topa's mouths on the tube. In anger, he killed Delgnat's dog and Topa. But Delgnat was unrepentant and insisted that Partholón was to blame, as leaving them alone together was like leaving honey before a woman, milk before a cat, edged tools before a craftsman, or meat before a child, and expecting them not to take advantage. This is recorded as the first case of adultery and the first jealousy in Ireland. The island in question was named Inis Saimera after Saimer, Delgnat's dog. === ''Annals of the Four Masters'' === The ''[[Annals of the Four Masters]]'' says they arrived in 2520 [[Anno Mundi]] (after the "[[Genesis creation narrative|creation of the world]]"). This work states that the plague came 300 years after their arrival, in May and tat one man survived: [[Tuan mac Cairill|Tuan]], son of Partholón's brother Starn. Through a series of animal transformations, he survived through the centuries to be reborn as the son of a chieftain named Cairell in the time of [[Columba|Colm Cille]] (6th century). He remembered all he had seen, and thus preserved Partholón's story. === Others === Other accounts differ in the timing of Partholón's arrival in Ireland. Later sources say Partholón died there after thirty years in Ireland, and the rest of his people also died there of plague. Other medieval texts say they arrived in the 60th year of [[Abraham]]. Partholon's brother Tait was the great-grandfather of [[Nemed]]. {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Cessair]]| title=[[Lebor Gabála Érenn|Mythical settlers of Ireland]]| after=[[Nemed]]| years=[[Annals of the Four Masters|AFM]] 2680 BC
[[Seathrún Céitinn|FFE]] 2061 BC| }} {{s-end}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == * {{cite book|last1=Nennius|editor-last=Morris|editor-first=John|title=British history ; and The Welsh annals|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=4xkXAQAAIAAJ}}|year=1980|publisher=Phillimore|isbn=978-0-8476-6264-7}} * {{cite book|editor-last=Macalister|editor-first=Robert Alexander Stewart|title=Lebor gabála Érenn: The book of the taking of Ireland|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=1tdfAAAAMAAJ}}|year=1956|publisher=Irish Texts Society|ref=harv}} [http://www.maryjones.us/ctexts/leborgabala.html Mary Jones] * {{cite book|editor-last=O'Donovan|editor-first=John|title=Annals of the Kingdom of Ireland by the four masters, from the earliest period to the year 1616: Ed. from the autograph. manuscript with a transl. and copious notes by John O'Donovan|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=Gb0_AAAAcAAJ}}|year=1848|publisher=Hodges and Smith}} [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005A/index.html UCC] * {{cite book|last=Keating|first=Geoffrey|editor-first1=D. |editor-last1=Comyn |editor-first2=P. S. |editor-last2=Dineen |title=The History of Ireland: by Geoffrey Keating|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=hWykuWFyZcEC}}|date=June 1983|publisher=Irish Roots Cafe|isbn=978-0-940134-47-8}} [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100054/index.html UCC] * {{cite book|last=Morris|first=John|title=The Age of Arthur: A History of the British Isles from 350 to 650|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w-xdPgAACAAJ|date=11 August 1998|publisher=Phoenix|isbn=978-1-85799-286-1}} * {{cite book|last=Mackillop|first=James|title=A Dictionary of Celtic Mythology|url={{google books |plainurl=y id=HQwbMQAACAAJ}}|date=14 January 2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-880484-0}} {{Celtic mythology (Mythological)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Partholon}} [[Category:Mythological cycle]] [[Category:Japhetic people]] [[Category:Irish people]]

revision.comment: She is not Malaysian and Indonesian descent.
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=August 2017}} {{notability|Biographies|date=August 2017}} {{one source|date=August 2017}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}} }} {{Infobox person | name = Patty Wong | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|10|29|mf=yes}} | birth_place = Lima, Peru | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Businesswoman]], [[Television presenter|TV presenter]], [[Model (profession)|model]] | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = {{ubl|{{marriage|Paolo Arroyo|2009|2010|reason=divorced}}}} | partner = | children = Ariatna Guadalupe (b. 2005) | parents = | relatives = | awards = Miss Perú Tusán (2001)
2nd runner-up in Mrs. Universe (2016) http://larepublica.pe/espectaculos/800033-patty-wong-dejo-en-alto-al-peru-quedo-como-segunda-finalista-del-mrs-universe-2016 }} '''Patty Wong''' (born October 29, 1980 in [[Lima]], [[Peru]]) is a Peruvian model. She formerly co-hosted a popular youth-oriented Peruvian show called ''R con R''. She also won in "Miss Perú Tusan," a beauty contest for [[Chinese Peruvian|Peruvian-Chinese]] girls, like her. She also co-hosts a Peruvian television show in the singing talent contest format, called ''Camino a la fama''. She was also the host of the cancelled children's show ''Zoombate'' along with Cati Caballero as co-host, another famous Peruvian model that started her career in ''R con R''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20050426051455/http://www.perumodelos.net/MODELOS/105/ Information and Photos] {{DEFAULTSORT:Wong, Patty}} [[Category:Peruvian people]] [[Category:People from Lima]] [[Category:Peruvian women in business]] [[Category:Peruvian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Peruvian television presenters]] [[Category:Peruvian female models]] [[Category:1980 births]] [[Category:Living people]] {{peru-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} [[File:Ranbir Kapoor promoting Barfi! at Cafe Coffee Day.jpg|thumb|upright=1|alt=An upper body shot of Ranbir Kapoor|Kapoor at an event for ''[[Barfi!]]'' in 2012. His performance in the film earned him his second consecutive [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor]].]] [[Ranbir Kapoor]] is an Indian actor and film producer who appears in [[Bollywood|Hindi films]]. He began his career as an assistant director on the films ''[[Aa Ab Laut Chalen]]'' (1999) and ''[[Black (2005 film)|Black]]'' (2005), before making his acting debut opposite [[Sonam Kapoor]] in [[Sanjay Leela Bhansali]]'s romantic drama ''[[Saawariya]]'' (2007).{{cite web|last=Masand |first=Rajeev |title=As a kid, I used to be petrified of dad |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/as-a-kid-i-used-to-be-petrified-of-dad-ranbir/49658-8.html |publisher=[[CNN-News18]] |date=1 October 2007 |accessdate=28 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009233647/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/as-a-kid-i-used-to-be-petrified-of-dad-ranbir/49658-8.html |archivedate= 9 October 2013 |df= }} It was a commercial failure but earned Kapoor a [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut]].{{cite web|publisher=[[Box Office India]] |title=Box Office 2007 |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=214&catName=MjAwNw== |accessdate=8 January 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014132441/http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=214&catName=MjAwNw%3D%3D |archivedate=14 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news |title=All Filmfare Award Winners |url=https://www.filmfare.com/awards/filmfare-awards/ |work=[[Filmfare]] |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180227163020/https://www.filmfare.com/awards/filmfare-awards/ |archivedate=27 February 2018 |df= }} He established himself in 2009 with leading roles in three films{{mdash}}the coming-of-age drama ''[[Wake Up Sid]]'', the comedy ''[[Ajab Prem Ki Ghazab Kahani]]'' and the drama ''[[Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year]]''. He won the [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor]] for his combined work in these three films. In 2010, Kapoor played a character based on [[Arjuna]] and [[Michael Corleone]] in the commercially successful political thriller ''[[Raajneeti]]''.{{cite web |title=Ranbir Kapoor |url=https://boxofficeindia.com/actor.php?actorid=11 |publisher=Box Office India |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912203525/http://boxofficeindia.com/actor.php?actorid=11 |archivedate=12 September 2017 |df= }}{{cite news |last=Gupta |first=Pratim D. |url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1100605/jsp/entertainment/story_12530049.jsp |title=She in a he world |work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]] |date=5 June 2010 |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608130100/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1100605/jsp/entertainment/story_12530049.jsp |archivedate=8 June 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|first=Nikhat|last=Kazmi|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Raajneeti/movie-review/6007822.cms|title=Raajneeti Movie Review|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=3 June 2010|accessdate=11 June 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120820214326/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Raajneeti/movie-review/6007822.cms|archive-date=20 August 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} From 2011 to 2013, Kapoor starred in top-grossing films of each individual year.{{cite web|title=Top Worldwide Grossers All Time |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/worldwide-total-gross.php |publisher=Box Office India |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180107113404/http://boxofficeindia.com/worldwide-total-gross.php |archivedate=7 January 2018 |accessdate=5 February 2018 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web |title=Top India Total Nett Gross 2011 |url=https://boxofficeindia.com/years.php?year=2011&pageId=4 |publisher=Box Office India |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008201029/https://boxofficeindia.com/years.php?year=2011&pageId=4 |archivedate=8 October 2017 |df= }} In [[Imtiaz Ali (director)|Imtiaz Ali]]'s musical ''[[Rockstar (2011 film)|Rockstar]]'' (2011), he played an aspiring singer, and in [[Anurag Basu]]'s comedy-drama ''[[Barfi!]]'' (2012), he starred as a joyful deaf and mute man.{{cite news |last=Vijaykumar |first=Neeti |url=https://www.theweek.in/webworld/features/society/ranbir-kapoor-career-defining-performances.html |title=7 career-defining performances of Ranbir Kapoor |work=The Week |date=28 September 2016 |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180414111959/https://www.theweek.in/webworld/features/society/ranbir-kapoor-career-defining-performances.html |archivedate=14 April 2018 |df= }} His performance in both films was critically acclaimed and he earned two consecutive [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] awards at Filmfare and the former also earned him a Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor.{{cite web |url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/ranbir-kapoor-last-five-years-have-been-amazing-612049 |title=Ranbir Kapoor: Last five years have been amazing |publisher=[[NDTV]] |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=18 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180718140927/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/ranbir-kapoor-last-five-years-have-been-amazing-612049 |archive-date=18 July 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|title=Filmfare Awards 2012: List of awardees |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/movies/story/filmfare-awards-2012-list-of-awardees-91395-2012-01-30 |work=India Today |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=14 April 2018 }}{{cite news |title=Barfi!, Kahaani dominate at Filmfare Awards; Ranbir and Vidya best actors |url=https://www.firstpost.com/sports/barfi-kahaani-dominate-at-filmfare-awards-ranbir-and-vidya-best-actors-595639.html |work=Firstpost |date=21 January 2013 |accessdate=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180414102315/https://www.firstpost.com/sports/barfi-kahaani-dominate-at-filmfare-awards-ranbir-and-vidya-best-actors-595639.html |archivedate=14 April 2018 |df= }} The romantic comedy ''[[Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani]]'' (2013) grossed over {{INRConvert|2.95|b|lk=r|year=2013}} to emerge as one of [[List of highest-grossing Bollywood films|Indian cinema's highest grossers]].{{cite news|title=Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani is Ranbir Kapoor, Deepika Padukone's biggest hit |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/yeh-jawaani-hai-deewani-is-ranbir-kapoor-deepika-padukone-s-biggest-hit/1127672/ |accessdate=1 July 2013 |work=The Indian Express |date=1 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130716115517/http://www.indianexpress.com/news/yeh-jawaani-hai-deewani-is-ranbir-kapoor-deepika-padukone-s-biggest-hit/1127672 |archivedate=16 July 2013 |df= }} This success was followed by roles in a series of commercial failures, including the period crime drama ''[[Bombay Velvet]]'' (2015), the romance ''[[Tamasha (2015 film)|Tamasha]]'' (2015), and the comic mystery ''[[Jagga Jasoos]]'' (2017); the latter also marked Kapoor's production debut under Picture Shuru Productions, which he formed with Anurag Basu.{{cite news |title=Ranbir Kapoor,Anurag Basu launch production house |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/ranbir-kapoor-anurag-basu-launch-production-house/ |accessdate=11 June 2013 |work=The Indian Express |date=14 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421033146/http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/ranbir-kapoor-anurag-basu-launch-production-house/ |archivedate=21 April 2014 |df= }} His sole commercial success in this period came with [[Karan Johar]]'s romance ''[[Ae Dil Hai Mushkil]]'' (2016), in which he starred opposite [[Anushka Sharma]] as a musician involved in a one-sided love affair.{{cite news|last=Leydon |first=Joe |title=Film Review: ‘Ae Dil Hai Mushkil’ |url=https://variety.com/2016/film/reviews/ae-dil-hai-mushkil-review-1201903527/ |work=Variety |date=28 October 2016 |accessdate=14 January 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161029110812/http://variety.com/2016/film/reviews/ae-dil-hai-mushkil-review-1201903527/ |archivedate=29 October 2016 |df= }} Kapoor made a career comeback in 2018 when he portrayed the troubled actor [[Sanjay Dutt]] in [[Rajkumar Hirani]]'s biopic ''[[Sanju]]'', which grossed over {{INRConvert|5.79|b}} to emerge as his highest-grossing release.{{cite web|url=https://www.timesnownews.com/entertainment/news/bollywood-news/article/exclusive-ranbir-kapoors-sanju-will-become-the-third-biggest-bollywood-film-ever-predicts-co-producer/255787|title=Exclusive: Ranbir Kapoor's Sanju will become the third biggest Bollywood film ever, predicts co-producer|accessdate=13 August 2018|date=18 July 2018|publisher=[[Times Now]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180814001619/https://www.timesnownews.com/entertainment/news/bollywood-news/article/exclusive-ranbir-kapoors-sanju-will-become-the-third-biggest-bollywood-film-ever-predicts-co-producer/255787|archive-date=14 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/box-office-special-features/box-office-sanju-now-6th-highest-bollywood-grosser-worldwide/|title=Box Office: Sanju is now the 6th highest Bollywood grosser worldwide|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|date=27 July 2018|accessdate=28 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180728002914/http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/box-office-special-features/box-office-sanju-now-6th-highest-bollywood-grosser-worldwide/|archive-date=28 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ==Film== {| class="wikitable" |+Key | style="background:#ffc;"| {{dagger|alt=Films that have not yet been released}} | Denotes films that have not yet been released |} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- style="text-align:center;" ! scope="col"|Film ! scope="col"|Year ! scope="col"|Role ! scope="col"|Director(s) ! class="unsortable" scope="col"|Notes ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{Tooltip|Ref(s).|Reference(s)}} |- !scope="row"| ''[[Aa Ab Laut Chalen]]'' | 1999 | style="text-align:center;"| — | {{sort|Kapoor|[[Rishi Kapoor]]}} | Assistant director |style="text-align:center;"|{{cite news|last=Rosario|first=Kennith|title=The extraordinary world of Ranbir Kapoor|url=http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/the-extraordinary-world-of-ranbir-kapoor/article19232527.ece|work=The Hindu|date=7 July 2017|accessdate=14 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180414102315/http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/movies/the-extraordinary-world-of-ranbir-kapoor/article19232527.ece|archivedate=14 April scope="col"| Title ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Role ! scope="col"| Performer(s) ! scope="col"| Album ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{Tooltip|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- ! scope="row"| "[[Mile Sur Mera Tumhara|Phir Mile Sur Mera Tumhara]]" | 2010 | Himself | Various | {{mdash}} | style="text-align: center;"|{{cite news|title=Amitabh launches new version of Mile sur mera tumhara |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/amitabh-launches-new-version-of-mile-sur-mera-tumhara/article1-501675.aspx |work=Hindustan Times |date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=7 June 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150708033525/http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/amitabh-launches-new-version-of-mile-sur-mera-tumhara/article1-501675.aspx |archivedate= 8 July 2015 |df= }} |} ==See also== *[[List of awards and nominations received by Ranbir Kapoor]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=1633541|name=Ranbir Kapoor}} * [http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/celebrity/ranbir-kapoor/ Ranbir Kapoor] on [[Bollywood Hungama]] {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kapoor, Ranbir filmography}} [[Category:Indian filmographies]] [[Category:Actor filmographies]]
